ghainīyek "wife"; derived from gharinī [9]; pɒtni "wife" [224:71];     from [292], two or three terms for  wife, but only in grammar-context:  p ribar "the wife" (without affix)  and  gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni) "the wife", with affixes for the honorific superior or for the feminine  -z ni ,  so without these affixes it would be  gh iniek (ghoiniyek)  (citation of text: Definitives: In Assamese, some post positional words or affixes are added to nouns, adjectives and numerals and these are having the sense of definite article “the” and after attached to the word much definitive becomes a part of the word. So case-suffixes are added to the definite eg- 
-g raki: Generally used to with the word showing much respect-  
 masnuh g raki  “the man/ the body” 
 p ribar g raki   “the wife” 
[...]
-z n / -z na/ -z ni:  honorific superior/ feminine respectively         gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni)    “the wife” )  [292]

So case-suffixes are added to the definite eg- 
-g raki: Generally used to with the word showing much respect-  
 masnuh g raki  “the man/ the body” 
 p ribar g raki   “the wife” 
[...]
-z n / -z na/ -z ni:  honorific superior/ feminine respectively         gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni)    “the wife” )  [292]

ghainīyek "wife"; derived from gharinī [9]; pɒtni "wife" [224:71];     from [292], two or three terms for  wife, but only in grammar-context:  p ribar "the wife" (without affix)  and  gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni) "the wife", with affixes for the honorific superior or for the feminine  -z ni ,  so without these affixes it would be  gh iniek (ghoiniyek)  (citation of text: Definitives: In Assamese, some post positional words or affixes are added to nouns, adjectives and numerals and these are having the sense of definite article “the” and after attached to the word much definitive becomes a part of the word. So case-suffixes are added to the definite eg- 
-g raki: Generally used to with the word showing much respect-  
 masnuh g raki  “the man/ the body” 
 p ribar g raki   “the wife” 
[...]
-z n / -z na/ -z ni:  honorific superior/ feminine respectively         gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni)    “the wife” )  [292]

ghainīyek "wife"; derived from gharinī [9]; pɒtni "wife" [224:71];     from [292], two or three terms for  wife, but only in grammar-context:  p ribar "the wife" (without affix)  and  gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni) "the wife", with affixes for the honorific superior or for the feminine  -z ni ,  so without these affixes it would be  gh iniek (ghoiniyek)  (citation of text: Definitives: In Assamese, some post positional words or affixes are added to nouns, adjectives and numerals and these are having the sense of definite article “the” and after attached to the word much definitive becomes a part of the word. So case-suffixes are added to the definite eg- 
-g raki: Generally used to with the word showing much respect-  
 masnuh g raki  “the man/ the body” 
 p ribar g raki   “the wife” 
[...]
-z n / -z na/ -z ni:  honorific superior/ feminine respectively         gh iniekz ni (ghoiniyekz ni)    “the wife” )  [292]
